sn3.5:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.5:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.5:1.3.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn3.5:1.3.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind.

sn3.5:1.4.pli: ‘kesaṃ nu kho rakkhito attā, kesaṃ arakkhito attā’ti?
sn3.5:1.4.eng: ‘Who are those who protect themselves? And who are those who don’t protect themselves?’
sn3.5:1.4.comm: For “protect themselves” (rakkhito attā) compare rakkhitatta at SN 6.13:2.4, Thag 2.11:2.4. The use of the term attā here is conventional, not metaphysical. “Personal safety” ( ātmarakṣā) is a paramount concern of kings (eg. Arthaśāstra 1.1.3, 1.21.30, 5.4.16, 7.3.24, 9.6.40, 12.2.10).

sn3.5:1.6.pli: ‘ye kho keci kāyena duccaritaṃ caranti, vācāya duccaritaṃ caranti, manasā duccaritaṃ caranti;
sn3.5:1.6.eng: ‘Those who do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind

sn3.5:1.8.pli: Kiñcāpi te hatthikāyo vā rakkheyya, assakāyo vā rakkheyya, rathakāyo vā rakkheyya, pattikāyo vā rakkheyya;
sn3.5:1.8.eng: Even if they’re protected by a company of elephants, cavalry, chariots, or infantry,

sn3.5:1.11.pli: Bāhirā hesā rakkhā, nesā rakkhā ajjhattikā;
sn3.5:1.11.eng: Because such protection is exterior, not interior.

sn3.5:1.12.eng: That’s why they don’t protect themselves.

sn3.5:1.13.pli: Ye ca kho keci kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti;
sn3.5:1.13.eng: Those who do good things by way of body, speech, and mind

sn3.5:1.15.pli: Kiñcāpi te neva hatthikāyo rakkheyya, na assakāyo rakkheyya, na rathakāyo rakkheyya, na pattikāyo rakkheyya;
sn3.5:1.15.eng: Even if they’re not protected by a company of elephants, cavalry, chariots, or infantry,

sn3.5:1.18.pli: Ajjhattikā hesā rakkhā, nesā rakkhā bāhirā;
sn3.5:1.18.eng: Because such protection is interior, not exterior.

sn3.5:1.19.eng: That’s why they do protect themselves.’”

sn3.5:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!” said the Buddha. And he repeated the king’s statement, adding:

sn3.5:2.2.pli: Ye hi keci, mahārāja, kāyena duccaritaṃ caranti …pe…

sn3.5:2.5.pli: Bāhirā hesā, mahārāja, rakkhā, nesā rakkhā ajjhattikā;

sn3.5:2.7.pli: Ye hi keci, mahārāja, kāyena sucaritaṃ caranti, vācāya sucaritaṃ caranti, manasā sucaritaṃ caranti;

sn3.5:2.9.pli: Kiñcāpi te neva hatthikāyo rakkheyya, na assakāyo rakkheyya, na rathakāyo rakkheyya, na pattikāyo rakkheyya;

sn3.5:2.12.pli: Ajjhattikā hesā, mahārāja, rakkhā, nesā rakkhā bāhirā;

sn3.6:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.6:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.6:1.3.pli: “idha mayhaṃ, bhante, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn3.6:1.3.eng: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:

sn3.6:1.4.pli: ‘appakā te sattā lokasmiṃ ye uḷāre uḷāre bhoge labhitvā na ceva majjanti, na ca pamajjanti, na ca kāmesu gedhaṃ āpajjanti, na ca sattesu vippaṭipajjanti.
sn3.6:1.4.eng: ‘Few are the sentient beings in the world who, when they obtain luxury possessions, don’t grow indulgent and negligent, giving in to greed for sensual pleasures, and doing the wrong thing by others.
sn3.6:1.4.comm: Again Pasenadi shows his reflective side, expressing evergreen wisdom.

sn3.6:1.5.pli: Atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā lokasmiṃ ye uḷāre uḷāre bhoge labhitvā majjanti ceva pamajjanti ca kāmesu ca gedhaṃ āpajjanti, sattesu ca vippaṭipajjantī’”ti.
sn3.6:1.5.eng: There are many more who, when they obtain luxury possessions, do grow indulgent and negligent, giving in to greed for sensual pleasures, and doing the wrong thing by others.’”

sn3.6:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!” said the Buddha. And he repeated the king’s statement, adding:

sn3.6:2.2.pli: Appakā te, mahārāja, sattā lokasmiṃ, ye uḷāre uḷāre bhoge labhitvā na ceva majjanti, na ca pamajjanti, na ca kāmesu gedhaṃ āpajjanti, na ca sattesu vippaṭipajjanti.

sn3.6:2.3.pli: Atha kho eteva bahutarā sattā lokasmiṃ, ye uḷāre uḷāre bhoge labhitvā majjanti ceva pamajjanti ca kāmesu ca gedhaṃ āpajjanti, sattesu ca vippaṭipajjantī”ti.

sn3.6:3.1.eng: “Full of desire for possessions and pleasures,

sn3.6:3.3.eng: they don’t notice that they’ve gone too far,

sn3.6:3.4.eng: like deer falling into a trap set out.

sn3.6:3.5.comm: Pacchāsaṁ resolves to pacchā esaṁ (“later for them”).

sn3.6:3.6.eng: for the result will be bad for them.”

sn3.7:1.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.7:1.2.eng: Seated to one side, King Pasenadi said to the Buddha,

sn3.7:1.3.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhante, aḍḍakaraṇe nisinno passāmi khattiyamahāsālepi brāhmaṇamahāsālepi gahapatimahāsālepi aḍḍhe mahaddhane mahābhoge pahūtajātarūparajate pahūtavittūpakaraṇe pahūtadhanadhaññe kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsante.
sn3.7:1.3.eng: “Sir, when I’m sitting in court I see well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain. But they tell deliberate lies for the sake of sensual pleasures.
sn3.7:1.3.comm: In the previous Sutta, Pasenadi lamented the corrupting influence of wealth. Here he talks of how he sees this corruption in his court. he speaks further of his frustrations at MN 98:13.1. | Read aḍḍa (variants attha, aṭṭa) which in Sanskrit has the senses “solve, infer, argue, discern”. The commentary interprets aḍḍakaraṇa as the “place of judgement” i.e. the court, which is clearly the case at DN 17:1.11.1.

sn3.7:1.5.pli: ‘alaṃ dāni me aḍḍakaraṇena, bhadramukho dāni aḍḍakaraṇena paññāyissatī’”ti.
sn3.7:1.5.eng: ‘Enough with passing judgment today. Now my dearest will be known by the judgments he makes.’”
sn3.7:1.5.comm: Bhadramukha is used here by by a king of his grown son. Elsewhere, by a family for a child (MN 40:6.2); by lay people addressing monks (MN 81:21.1); by a laywoman addressing a deity (AN 7.53:3.4);  (SN 3.7:1.5); and, with the addition of the familiar tāta, by a brahmin wife to her husband (MN 100:3.5). The term is of Sanskritic form and is found commonly in the Avadāna literature. Turning to later Sanskrit sources, Nāṭyaśāstra 19.12 says it should be used when addressing inferiors, while Sāhityadarpaṇa 6.154 says it is used when addressing a prince (see SN 3.7 above). The early Pali usage, however, suggests it was an affectionate and respectful term of somewhat elevated usage, but not restricted by status. Since bhadda by itself is a common form of address in the sense “my dear”, I think the suffix -mukha has its intensive sense here, “dearest”, rather than “dear face”.

sn3.7:2.1.eng: “That’s so true, great king! That’s so true!

sn3.7:2.2.pli: Yepi te, mahārāja, khattiyamahāsālā brāhmaṇamahāsālā gahapatimahāsālā aḍḍhā mahaddhanā mahābhogā pahūtajātarūparajatā pahūtavittūpakaraṇā pahūtadhanadhaññā kāmahetu kāmanidānaṃ kāmādhikaraṇaṃ sampajānamusā bhāsanti;
sn3.7:2.2.eng: Those who are well-to-do aristocrats, brahmins, and householders tell deliberate lies for the sake of sensual pleasures.

sn3.7:2.3.pli: tesaṃ taṃ bhavissati dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
sn3.7:2.3.eng: That is for their lasting harm and suffering.”

sn3.7:2.4.eng: That is what the Buddha said. …

sn3.7:3.1.eng: “Full of desire for possessions and pleasures,

sn3.7:3.3.eng: they don’t notice that they’ve gone too far,

sn3.7:3.4.eng: like fish entering a net set out.

sn3.7:3.6.eng: for the result will be bad for them.”

sn3.8:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā pasenadi kosalo mallikāya deviyā saddhiṃ uparipāsādavaragato hoti.
sn3.8:1.2.eng: Now at that time King Pasenadi of Kosala was upstairs in the royal longhouse together with Queen Mallikā.
sn3.8:1.2.comm: In addition to conversations on the theme of attachment to loved ones (MN 87, Ud 5.1), unrelated incidents with Mallikā appear at AN 4.197, Bu Pc 53:1.1, and Bu Pc 83:1.2.7. She is listed as an eminent lay disciple (AN 8.91–117:1.1) and maintained a monastery for philosophical debates (MN 78:1.3). Her passing is recorded at AN 5.49. This is what we know of her from early texts, while later Jātakas and other scriptures tell many colorful tales about her and her unique marriage. | Śvetāmbara Jains hold that, in the far distant past, the nineteenth founding teacher (tīrthaṅkara) was the lady Malli (Triṣaṣṭiśalākāpuruṣacaritra 6.6). Perhaps the Buddhist stories of the wise lady Mallikā helped inspire this legend.

sn3.8:1.3.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavoca:
sn3.8:1.3.eng: Then the king said to the queen,

sn3.8:1.4.pli: “atthi nu kho te, mallike, kocañño attanā piyataro”ti?
sn3.8:1.4.eng: “Mallikā, is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”
sn3.8:1.4.comm: This passage echoes Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.4.8: “The Self is more dear than a son, than wealth, than everything else.” The reason, it argues, is that only the Self is immortal, not those who are dear. Pasenadi is of course using “self” in a conventional rather than metaphysical sense.

sn3.8:1.5.pli: “Natthi kho me, mahārāja, kocañño attanā piyataro.
sn3.8:1.5.comm: Mallikā’s reply is brave, given that she is telling her king and husband she loves herself more than him. This passage alludes to the famous dialogue where Yājñavalkya explains to his wife Maitreyī that he is renouncing in order to seek the true Self.

sn3.8:1.6.pli: Tuyhaṃ pana, mahārāja, atthañño koci attanā piyataro”ti?
sn3.8:1.6.eng: But is there anyone more dear to you than yourself?”

sn3.8:1.7.pli: “Mayhampi kho, mallike, natthañño koci attanā piyataro”ti.

sn3.8:2.1.pli: Atha kho rājā pasenadi kosalo pāsādā orohitvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā pasenadi kosalo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn3.8:2.1.eng: Then King Pasenadi of Kosala came downstairs from the stilt longhouse, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

sn3.8:2.2.pli: “idhāhaṃ, bhante, mallikāya deviyā saddhiṃ uparipāsādavaragato mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavocaṃ:

sn3.8:2.3.pli: ‘atthi nu kho te, mallike, kocañño attanā piyataro’ti?

sn3.8:2.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, mallikā devī maṃ etadavoca:

sn3.8:2.5.pli: ‘natthi kho me, mahārāja, kocañño attanā piyataro.

sn3.8:2.6.pli: Tuyhaṃ pana, mahārāja, atthañño koci attanā piyataro’ti?

sn3.8:2.7.pli: Evaṃ vuttāhaṃ, bhante, mallikaṃ deviṃ etadavocaṃ:

sn3.8:2.8.pli: ‘mayhampi kho, mallike, natthañño koci attanā piyataro’”ti.

sn3.8:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imaṃ gāthaṃ abhāsi:
sn3.8:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha spoke this verse:

sn3.8:4.1.eng: “Having explored every quarter with the mind,

sn3.8:4.2.eng: one finds no-one dearer than oneself.

sn3.8:4.3.eng: Likewise for others, each holds themselves dear;
sn3.8:4.3.comm: Care for oneself is not selfishness. This is an expression of the Golden Rule.

sn3.8:4.4.eng: so one who desires self-knowledge would harm no other.”

sn3.9:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rañño pasenadissa kosalassa mahāyañño paccupaṭṭhito hoti, pañca ca usabhasatāni pañca ca vacchatarasatāni pañca ca vacchatarisatāni pañca ca ajasatāni pañca ca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya.
sn3.9:1.2.eng: Now at that time a big sacrifice had been set up for King Pasenadi of Kosala. Bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats and rams—five hundred of each—had been led to the pillar for the sacrifice.
sn3.9:1.2.comm: It would be strange for a devoted Buddhist to undertake such a sacrifice. Perhaps this was before Pasenadi converted. The commentary, however, says that it was in response to a terrifying nightmare, on the advice of his brahmin priest. While it is true that Buddhism has mostly ended cruel sacrifices, I have heard of such things in Buddhist communities even in modern times.

sn3.9:1.3.pli: Yepissa te honti dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karonti.
sn3.9:1.3.eng: His bondservants, servants, and workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.

sn3.9:2.1.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya sāvatthiṃ piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu.
sn3.9:2.1.eng: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.

sn3.9:2.2.pli: Sāvatthiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
sn3.9:2.2.eng: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.

sn3.9:2.3.pli: “idha, bhante, rañño pasenadissa kosalassa mahāyañño paccupaṭṭhito hoti, pañca ca usabhasatāni pañca ca vacchatarasatāni pañca ca vacchatarisatāni pañca ca ajasatāni pañca ca urabbhasatāni thūṇūpanītāni honti yaññatthāya.

sn3.9:2.4.pli: Yepissa te honti dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi daṇḍatajjitā bhayatajjitā assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni karontī”ti.

sn3.9:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā etamatthaṃ viditvā tāyaṃ velāyaṃ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn3.9:3.1.eng: Then, understanding this matter, on that occasion the Buddha recited these verses:
sn3.9:3.1.comm: The rituals listed are grand sacrifices requiring the slaughter of many beasts, intended to establish or grow the power of the king. Not all are readily identifiable in Vedic texts.

sn3.9:4.1.comm: The horse sacrifice (assamedha, Sanskrit aśvamedha) was expensive, dangerous, and rarely performed. A horse was set free for a year, followed by the king and his army who would conquer any lands on which it strayed. Then it was killed in an obscene rite. It appears in the late stages of the Rig Veda (1.162, 1.163, and perhaps 10.86) and was a major feature of the sacrificial systems (eg. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 13) and cosmic meditations (Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 1.1). | Even before the Buddha, human sacrifice was regarded by the Vedists as a long-abandoned practice, substituted by a horse, then an ox, a sheep, and finally a goat, and finally as rice and barley (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.2.3.6; compare Genesis 22). It persisted, however, in darker corners of Indian folk religion.

sn3.9:4.2.eng: the ‘casting of the yoke-pin’, <j>the ‘royal soma drinking’,
sn3.9:4.2.comm: The “casting of the yoke-pin” (sammāpāsa) is obscure. I think it originated as the pulling out of a yoke-pin (śamyā) of the beasts of the journey, which were cast about at journey’s end to establish one’s territory (see Manu 8.237). | The “royal soma drinking” (vājapeyya) is a rite where, after a horse race, the king drinks the soma, giving him superhuman strength and prowess in battle, and at which several animals, sometimes said to be seventeen, are sacrificed. This is said to be a higher sacrifice that establishes a king as emperor (see Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 5.1.1).

sn3.9:4.3.comm: The niraggaḷa is probably a form of the horse sacrifice where the horse is “unimpeded”, thus establishing the king as similarly unstoppable. The Buddha adopted the term for arahants (MN 22:34.1[).

sn3.9:4.4.eng: these huge violent sacrifices yield no great fruit.

sn3.9:5.1.eng: The great sages of right comportment

sn3.9:6.1.eng: But the great sages of right comportment

sn3.9:6.3.comm: The anukula (“propitious”) sacrifice is mentioned several times (eg. DN 5:22.4, AN 4.40:2.2). The Pali commentaries interpret it as “in line with (anu-) family (kula)”. But nothing in the contexts connects it with family customs, nor is such a term known in Sanskrit. It seems rather to be a misunderstanding of Sanskrit anukūla, literally “along the riverbank”, and in applied use, “in conformity with”, “favorable to”, as in the favor of the gods. This is the standard reading in Buddhist Sanskrit. Such a sacrifice is characterized, not by family custom, but by harmlessness. Thus anukula means “propitious, favored (by the gods and the Dhamma)”.

sn3.9:6.5.eng: and various creatures are not killed.

sn3.9:7.1.eng: A clever person should sacrifice like this,

sn3.9:7.2.eng: for this sacrifice is very fruitful.

sn3.9:7.3.eng: For a sponsor of sacrifices like this,

sn3.9:7.5.eng: Such a sacrifice is truly abundant,

sn3.9:7.6.eng: and even the deities are pleased.”

sn4.1:1.1.comm: The first five discourses of this chapter are set shortly after the Buddha’s awakening, and hence in the period of time covered in the first chapter of the Vinaya Khandhaka (Kd 1). However, despite the length of that narrative, only the fourth and fifth are included there. This situation mirrors the Mahāparinibbānasutta, where there are also events missing from the narrative as we have it. Either parts were lost, or the compilers left out some events for some reason.

sn4.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
sn4.1:1.2.eng: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying in Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.
sn4.1:1.2.comm: In modern times this is the pilgrimage site Bodhgaya in the Gaya district of Bihar. It lies by a wide river that is dry in summer but abundant in the rains. In Pali the river is called Nerañjarā, which  is of unclear meaning, but the commentary suggests “sweet waters” (nela-jala) or “blue waters” (nīla-jala). The Sanskrit is nairañjanā, which suggests the sense “unblemished”. Today it is called the Līlajan (or Nīlajan). | Uruvelā, which aptly means “Broadbanks”, was a locality centered around the market town of Senānigama (“Marshalltown”). There was also a sizable hermitage nearby with matted-hair Brahmanical ascetics (jaṭilā) who ritually bathed in the water (Kd 1:20.15.1). After teaching the five monks in Varanasi, the Buddha returned here to teach them, but there is no record of him visiting subsequently.

sn4.1:1.3.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
sn4.1:1.3.eng: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,

sn4.1:1.4.eng: “I am truly freed from that grueling work!
sn4.1:1.4.comm: “Grueling work” (dukkarakārikā) refers to the self-mortification he practiced for six years before awakening (MN 12:56.1, MN 100:27.5), which was similar to Jain practices (MN 14:17.5).

sn4.1:1.5.pli: Sādhu mutto vatamhi tāya anatthasaṃhitāya dukkarakārikāya.
sn4.1:1.5.eng: Thank goodness I’m freed from that pointless grueling work.

sn4.1:1.6.eng: Thank goodness I’m freed and have attained awakening.”
sn4.1:1.6.comm: I follow the MS reading here. Sinhalese editions have “steady, mindful” instead of “freed”. Commentary is silent.

sn4.1:2.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.1:2.1.eng: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing the Buddha’s train of thought, went up to him and addressed him in verse:
sn4.1:2.1.comm: Māra is sometimes called Namuci, and in fact seems to descend from the Vedic adversary of that name. Vedic Namuci “the wicked” (pāpmā vai namuciḥ, Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4) was a wily trickster (māyin, Rig Veda 1.53.7c) who was nonetheless outsmarted by Indra (Rig Veda 5.30.6c), and possessed ineffectual armies reliant on women (Rig Veda 5.30.9a). Buddhist Māra “the wicked” (māro pāpimā) was a wily trickster (passim) who was nonetheless outsmarted by the Buddha and his followers (passim); he possessed ineffectual armies (DN 20:21.3, AN 4.13:2.3, Snp 3.2), and sent his daughters to do his dirty work (SN 4.25). The decapitated head of Namuci introduced death (mṛtyu) in the form of blood to the deathless (amṛta) soma (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 12.7.3.4, Maitrāyaṇī Saṁhitā 4.4.4), establishing his Pali names Maccurāja, “King of Death” and Māra, “Death”. He appears in a similar guise in Jainism too (Ācaraṅga 1.3.1.3).

sn4.1:3.1.comm: Māra pretends to favor asceticism. Truth means nothing to him, as words are merely devices for him to get what he wants.

sn4.1:3.2.eng: by which sons of men purify themselves.

sn4.1:3.3.eng: You’re impure, but think yourself pure;

sn4.1:3.4.eng: you’ve strayed from the path of purity.”

sn4.1:4.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.1:4.1.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:

sn4.1:5.2.comm: The split compound amaraṁ tapaṁ also occurs at  Thag 3.1:1.4, and at Snp 2.2:11.4 we have amarā bahū tapā. The commentary explains that amara here is “immortality”, and the phrase means “fervent mortification aimed at immortality”. However, I find this unconvincing, one reason being that amara is an adjective (and thus must be glossed with an abstract noun in dative, amarabhāvatthāya). It is simpler to assume Pali has an idiomatic sense of amara as “endless”, which occurs here, in the phrase amarāvikkhepa (DN 1:2.23.1), and in the Niddesa’s amarāvitakka (Cnd 12:6.1). Then amarā and bahū are synonyms. I cannot find any use in Sanskrit that parallels this, but amara is noted by Edgerton in Buddhist Hybrid Sanskrit as “a high number”.

sn4.1:5.4.eng: as oars and rudder on dry land.
sn4.1:5.4.comm: Phiyāritta is the fittings for a boat at AN 4.196:8.12. Phiya is perhaps Hybrid Sanskrit sphija, “broom”. Aritta is Sanskrit aritra, “oar, rudder”. | Dhammani (Vedic dhanvan, “desert”) is the neuter noun dhamman in locative singular.

sn4.1:6.2.eng: by developing this path to awakening

sn4.1:6.4.comm: By calling Māra “terminator”, the Buddha makes plain the threat implicit in his name.

sn4.1:7.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti, dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.1:7.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.10:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati veḷuvane kalandakanivāpe.
sn4.10:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
sn4.10:1.2.comm: The Bamboo Grove was a major monastery near Rājagaha. According to Kd 1:22.16.1, it was offered by King Bimbisāra as the very first monastery dedicated to the Saṅgha.

sn4.10:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, the lifespan of humans is short.

sn4.10:2.2.pli: Gamanīyo samparāyo, kattabbaṃ kusalaṃ, caritabbaṃ brahmacariyaṃ.
sn4.10:2.2.eng: You must go to the next life. So you should do what is skillful, you should practice the spiritual life.

sn4.10:2.4.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, ciraṃ jīvati, so vassasataṃ appaṃ vā bhiyyo”ti.
sn4.10:2.4.eng: A long life is a hundred years or a little more.”
sn4.10:2.4.comm: A hundred years was the standard long life (eg. Snp 3.8:16.1, DN 14:3.30.5, AN 7.74:10.3).

sn4.10:3.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.10:3.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.10:4.1.eng: “The days and nights don’t rush by,

sn4.10:4.3.eng: The life of mortals keeps rolling on,

sn4.10:4.4.eng: like a chariot’s rim around the hub.”
sn4.10:4.4.comm: This echoes the idea that a wheeled chariot was unstoppable (SN 56.11:12.2), an idea arising from the Vedic conception of the Sun as a wheel.

sn4.10:5.2.eng: and then life is cut short.

sn4.10:5.3.eng: The life of mortals wastes away,

sn4.10:5.4.eng: like the water in tiny streams.”

sn4.10:6.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.10:6.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.11:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn4.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.

sn4.11:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā rattandhakāratimisāyaṃ abbhokāse nisinno hoti, devo ca ekamekaṃ phusāyati.
sn4.11:1.2.eng: Now at that time the Buddha was meditating in the open during the dark of night, while a gentle rain drizzled down.

sn4.11:1.3.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato bhayaṃ chambhitattaṃ lomahaṃsaṃ uppādetukāmo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavato avidūre mahante pāsāṇe padālesi.
sn4.11:1.3.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, wanting to make the Buddha feel fear, terror, and goosebumps, approached him, and crushed some large boulders close by him.

sn4.11:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.11:2.1.eng: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, addressed him in verse:

sn4.11:4.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.11:4.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

sn4.12:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn4.12:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn4.12:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn4.12:1.2.eng: Now, at that time the Buddha was teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

sn4.12:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo mahatiyā parisāya parivuto dhammaṃ deseti.
sn4.12:2.2.eng: “The ascetic Gotama is teaching Dhamma, surrounded by a large assembly.

sn4.12:2.3.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena samaṇo gotamo tenupasaṅkameyyaṃ vicakkhukammāyā”ti.
sn4.12:2.3.eng: Why don’t I go and pull the wool over their eyes?”

sn4.12:2.4.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
sn4.12:2.4.eng: Then Māra the Wicked went up to the Buddha and addressed him in verse:

sn4.12:3.1.eng: “Why now do you roar like a lion?

sn4.12:3.2.eng: You’re so self-assured in the assembly!

sn4.12:3.3.eng: For there is someone who’ll wrestle with you,

sn4.12:3.4.eng: so why do you imagine you’re the victor?”

sn4.12:4.3.eng: The Realized One, attained to power,
sn4.12:4.3.comm: The ten powers of a Realized One are detailed at AN 10.21 and MN 12:9.1.

sn4.12:4.4.eng: has crossed over clinging to the world.”

sn4.12:5.1.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
sn4.12:5.1.eng: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.
